means between these extremes. Hence we are justified in pronouncing this peculiarity to result
from an accidental outgrowth, which is so variable in its degree as not
to afford the least basis for specific differentiation. It is worthy of
note, however, that it presents itself far more frequently, and also in a
far more characteristic manner, in the Orbitolites of the Philippine Seas
than in those of the Australian or of any other Provinces; and this
circumstance seems to render it probable, that the outgrowth is directly
due to the influence of some external conditions, probably to an excess in the
proportion of carbonate of lime in the waters inhabited by these
particular specimens.

54 <u>Variations in Mode of Growth</u>._ Although the cyclical
mode of growth, when once established, is subsequently maintained
with great regularity, and although in what may be considered
the typical form, it commences from the 'nucleus' itself, yet there are
numerous instance in which the typical regularity is more or
less widely departed-from, so that the early increase seems to take
place after an altogether different plan. The most marked antithesis
to that regularly-concentric type of growth, in which a complete annulus
